questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the specimen :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carotid body tumor The image shows a carotid body tumor lies between the arteries , superficial to the vagus nerve and deep to the hypoglossal nerve . " Lyre sign " on an arteriogram of a carotid body paraganglioma demonstrates splaying of the internal and external carotid arteries .

Highyeild:

Criteria Vagal Paraganglioma Carotid Body Tumour Lipoma Neurilemmoma Location Originates from the vagus nerve Originates from the carotid body Subcutaneous, deep and visceral Originates from Schwann cells of peripheral nerves Symptoms Vocal cord palsy dysphagia, hoarseness, dyspnea Palpable neck mass, pulsatile tinnitus, headache, dizziness Asymptomatic may cause cosmetic concerns or interfere with function Numbness tingling weakness, pain, motor deficits Diagnosis MRI, CT, PET scan, biopsy MRI, CT, PET scan, biopsy Biopsy, ultrasound, MRI Biopsy, MRI, CT scan Treatment Surgical resection, radiation therapy, chemotherapy Surgical Resection, radiation therapy, chemotherapy Surgical excision Surgical resection, radiation therapy Prognosis Recurrence is rare, 5-year survival rate is >90% Recurrence is rare, 5-year survival rate is >90% Benign, low recurrence rate, excellent prognosis Recurrence is rare, 5-year survival rate is >90% Histology Glomus cells, S-100 positive Chromaffin cells S-100 positive Adipose cells Schwann cells, S-100 positive

questions.text: False about endoleak classification is:

options.label: A
options.text: Type 1 is the attachment site leak

options.label: D
options.text: Type 4 is an Endograft fabric porosity leak

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type 2 is Endo tension Endoleak classification: ● Type 1 ● Attachment site leak ● Type 2 ● Side branch leak caused by lumbar or inferior mesenteric arteries ● Type 3 ● Junctional leak (of overlapping Endograft components) and graft fabric defect ● Type 4 ● Endograft fabric porosity leak ● Type 5 ● Endo tension

Highyeild:

Type 1 and 3 endoleaks require repair in EVAR (endovascular aneurysm repair) Type 2 endoleaks are common early after EVAR and usually resolve within 1 to 6 months. Persistent type 2 endoleaks management is controversial, with most favoring observation if there is no sac growth. If sac growth occurs despite stable type 2 endoleak, delayed type 1 or 3 endoleak may be the underlying cause.

Extraedge:

Contrast-enhanced ultrasound is a valuable tool in patients who have undergone endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). It can aid in detecting, localizing, and measuring endoleaks after the procedure. Endoleaks are a complication that can occur after EVAR and require prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Not an indication of Carotid endarterectomy in a symptomatic patient with more than 70% stenosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ipsilateral facial paralysis Indications for carotid endarterectomy in symptomatic patients: 70% or greater carotid stenosis and: Ipsilateral amaurosis fugax or monocular blindness Contralateral facial paralysis or Paraesthesia Arm/leg paralysis or Paraesthesia Hemianopia Dysphasia (if dominant hemisphere) Sensory or visual inattention/neglect.

Highyeild:

Carotid endarterectomy is recommended for tight stenosis (>50%). The procedure involves clamping the vessels, making an arteriotomy in the common carotid artery, and removing the occlusive disease from the internal carotid artery. The arteriotomy is then closed, often with a patch. Surgeons may also use a temporary shunt to maintain cerebral blood flow while the carotid system is clamped.

Extraedge:

Subclavian artery stenosis can cause claudication in the arm or digital ischemia due to distal embolization. Mesenteric artery occlusive disease may cause intestinal angina (pain after eating) and weight loss.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presented with complaints of chest pain. He had a history of fatigability after activity for more than 10 days and felt chest tightness and chest pain for 4 days before admission. An emergency aortic computed tomographic (CT) scan showed a thickened aortic wall, bilateral pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion. Cardiac color ultrasound suggested aortic hematoma or dissection. The patient underwent an emergency operation for ascending aortic replacement and aortic arch replacement. Which classification of aortic dissection can be used in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

DeBakey classification There are two classifications of aortic dissectio n widely used. The DeBakey classification is based on the pattern of dissection, whereas the Stanford classification is based on whether the ascending aorta is involved (A). Crawford classification (C) is used to classify Thoraco-abdominal Aneurysms. Trans-Atlantic Inter-Society Consensus (TASC) is a classification system for iliac lesions(D)

Highyeild:

Clinical Features: Acute aortic dissection: characterized by sudden, severe, tearing pain, accompanied by sweating. Pain may be felt in the front or back of the chest, often in the interscapular region, and may shift as the dissection progresses. Other symptoms may include fainting, shortness of breath, and weakness. Physical examination may reveal hypertension or hypotension, absence of pulses, aortic regurgitation, pulmonary edema, and neurological symptoms caused by carotid artery obstruction or spinal cord ischemia.

Extraedge:

Ascending aortic dissection may be detected by the presence of a widened superior mediastinum on a chest X-ray. Pleural effusion, usually on the left side and typically serosanguineous, may be present. CT angiography is the imaging modality of choice for stable patients. Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred in unstable patients.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male had complaints of sudden onset excruciating chest-back “tearing” pain. ECG showed nonspecific ST changes. Computed tomography angiography (CTA), the initial rupture in the thoracic aorta was located 2 mm distal from the left subclavian artery (LSA), with dissection extending down to the branch of the abdominal aorta and partial involvement of the left iliac artery and was diagnosed with acute thoracic aortic dissection. Which type of aortic dissection can be managed medically?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type III Type I, II & III are classifications of aortic dissection based on DeBakey’s classification. TYPE B (OR TYPE III) DISSECTIONS Initially are best managed medically with antihypertensive drugs. Intervention is indicated in complicated cases if the pain increases (signaling impending rupture) or when dissection is associated with evidence of malperfusion, such as organ, limb, or neurological symptoms.

Highyeild:

Aortic dissection is caused by a tear in the intima, which can be circumferential or transverse. The most common site of aortic dissection is the right lateral wall of the ascending aorta. Another common site of aortic dissection is the descending thoracic aorta, just below the ligamentum arteriosum. Aortic dissection is most prevalent in the 6th and 7th decades of life. Men are more commonly affected by aortic dissection

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A & B. TYPE A (OR TYPE I AND II) DISSECTIONS (A, B) involving the ascending aorta usually require immediate surgical intervention. Option: D. Null option. No such thing exists.

Extraedge:

Type A dissection, if left untreated, has a high mortality rate of 50% within 48 hours and 75% within 1-2 weeks. Type B dissections have a better prognosis compared to Type A dissections. Surgical mortality rates for proximal aortic dissections vary but are typically around 20-25%. The overall survival rate for patients leaving the hospital, regardless of the type of dissection, is around 80% at 5 years and 40% at 10 years.

questions.text: A 61-year-old male with a history of hypertension presented with transient consciousness disturbance. He reported a sensation of being out of breath and then loss of consciousness. He denied headache, chest pain, back pain, and abdomen pain. Electrocardiogram (EKG) demonstrated normal sinus rhythm. There was increased C-reactive protein and D-dimer level. His chest radiography indicated a widening of the mediastinum, and contrast-enhanced chest CT demonstrated aortic dissection extending from the aortic root to the bifurcation of common iliac arteries. Which classification of aortic dissection can be used in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stanford Type A The two traditional classification schemes that remain in common use are the DeBakey and the Stanford classification systems. The DeBakey classification is based on the pattern of dissection , whereas the Stanford classification is based on whether the ascending aorta is involved. Dissection can be confined to the ascending aorta or the descending aorta, or it can involve the entire aorta which are classified as DeBakey Type II or Stanford Type A .

Highyeild:

Type A aortic dissection involves the ascending aorta, which is the portion of the aorta that begins at the heart and extends upward. Type B aortic dissection is limited to the descending aorta, which is the portion of the aorta that extends downward from the arch of the aorta.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. DeBakey Type III or Stanford Type B (B) DeBakey Type I or Stanford Type A respectively. Option: C & D. Crawford classification (C, D) is used to classify Thoraco-abdominal Aneurysms.

Extraedge:

The Penn modification of the Stanford classification is an updated version of the original classification system. It expands the classification by taking into account the presence of tissue and global malperfusion. improving the primary surgical intervention for aortic dissection. provide better guidance for clinical decision-making. These modifications have the potential to streamline the treatment process for aortic dissection patients.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presented with strong chest pain in the substernal area. She had a medical history of hypertension and had been on medication for 5 years. The pain was oppressive in nature and non-radiating pain. This excruciating pain lasted for about 10 minutes combined with a doomed feeling, diaphoresis, and difficulty in taking deep breaths. The patient had normal ECGs and serum marker levels. Which test can be used as a standard for diagnosis of the condition of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Computed tomography (CT) Diagnosis is confirmed by CT , which is accepted as the standard method for diagnosis. Other imaging modalities such as TOE (IOC in unstable patients) or MRI can be utilized in cases when the CT is equivocal.

Highyeild:

Contrast-enhanced CT is the primary diagnostic tool for aortic dissection, with high sensitivity (98%) and specificity (87%). CT scans allow for the swift acquisition of images and provide essential information about the segments of the aorta involved. The classic diagnostic feature of aortic dissection on CT is a double-lumen aorta. CT scans can also reveal the acuity of the dissection, aortic dilation (including preexisting degenerative aneurysms), and potential complications like pericardial effusion, early aortic rupture, and branch-vessel compromise.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Normal ECGs (A) and serum marker levels in patients with acute chest pain should raise suspicion about the possibility of aortic dissection. Options: B & D. Chest x-ray and MRI angiogram has low sensitivity, MRI is usually not available in an emergency, and requires time.

Extraedge:

Aortic dissection is typically diagnosed using a CT scan, but patients may also undergo aortography. Aortography can help determine the mechanism of malperfusion and correct it, making it beneficial for patients with this complication. While catheter-based aortography may be considered obsolete as a diagnostic tool for aortic dissection, it still has value for patients with malperfusion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was diagnosed with Aortic Dissection, Stanford type A by CT. Which one of the following is not a predisposing factor for Aortic dissection?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aortic stenosis Predisposing factors for aortic dissection includes Age, Hypertension, Marfan (A) syndrome, Pregnancy, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, Coarctation of the aorta, Turner or Noonan syndromes (B, C) and Aortic cannulation site (iatrogenic). The most common etiology for an aortic aneurysm is atherosclerosis , but connective tissue disorders account for many aneurysms in the aortic root and ascending aorta.

Highyeild:

Aortic stenosis in adults is commonly caused by a degenerative calcification process that makes the aortic valve cusps immobile. A congenitally abnormal valve can also cause aortic stenosis, mimicking the degenerative process, due to progressive fibrosis and calcification. The most frequent congenital abnormality is commissural fusion, which results in a bicuspid aortic valve. The bicuspid aortic valve occurs in approximately 1% of the population.

Extraedge:

Classification of the severity of aortic stenosis. Mild Moderate Severe Valve area (cm³) >1.5 1.0-1.5 <1.0 Mean gradient (mmHg) <20 20-40 >40 Velocity (m/s) 2.6-2.9 (<2.5 found in aortic sclerosis) 3.0-4.0 >4.0 Velocity ratio >0.50 0.25-0.50 <0.25

questions.text: A 45-year-old, male patient complained of sudden back pain, radiating between both scapula bones and shortness of breath. Electrocardiogram showed a positive ST segment in V3-V4 no more than 2mm, and no ischemic changes; a chest x-ray was performed without any positive finding. Chest CT demonstrated a dissection of the thoracic aorta of grade III as per the Debakey classification and type B as per Stanford classification. Which one of the following is not a potential complication of dissection of the aorta?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Potential complications of dissection of the aorta (and involved secondary arteries) may include cardiac ischemia (a) (coronary artery) or tamponade (c), stroke (brachiocephalic arteries), paraplegia or paraparesis (B) (intercostal arteries), mesenteric ischemia (superior mesenteric artery), kidney failure (renal arteries), and limb ischemia or loss of motor function (brachial or femoral arteries). Compromised blood flow to branch vessels causes ischemic complications.

Highyeild:

Ascending aortic dissection can damage the aortic valve, leading to regurgitation. The extent of valve damage depends on the level of commissural disruption. Partial separation of one commissure may cause mild regurgitation, while full separation of all three commissures can cause complete valve prolapse and severe heart failure. Patients with acute aortic valve regurgitation may experience rapidly worsening dyspnea.

Extraedge:

Arterial dissection can cause a variety of health problems. Complications depend on the affected arteries. Possible outcomes include stroke, paraplegia, hepatic failure, bowel infarction, renal failure, and threatened ischemic limb.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman had complaints of excruciating chest pain, described as a sudden, radiating to the back. Computed tomography showed a type A aortic dissection with the intimal tear in the aortic root. The dissection involved the entire aorta and both the common iliac arteries. The patient is having subclavian artery malperfusion as a complication of aortic dissection. What would be the most likely symptom the patient would experience?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cold, painful extremity For Subclavian or iliofemoral artery malperfusion , the symptoms and signs include cold, painful extremity, Extremity sensory and motor deficits, and Peripheral pulse deficit.

Highyeild:

Subclavian artery stenosis is commonly caused by atherosclerosis and often affects the left side. The first part of the subclavian artery is the most common site of stenosis, which can cause subclavian steal syndrom This syndrome results in reversed blood flow in the vertebral artery, stealing blood from the brain to feed the arm.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Paraplegia (a) is a sign of Spinal malperfusion. Option: C. Syncope (c) is a sign of Carotid artery malperfusion. Option: D. Shock (d) is a sign of Coronary malperfusion, Aortic valve insufficiency, and Pericardial tamponade.

questions.text: A contrast CT scan of the chest performed on a 54-year-old woman showed an aortic dissection extending from the aortic root along the right lateral wall of the aortic arch. The ascending aorta measured 5.7 cm transversely. The descending aorta appeared normal, measuring 2.5 cm at its widest diameter. In which of the following group, delayed treatment for ascending aortic dissection should not be considered?

options.label: A
options.text: In patients who present with severe acute stroke or mesenteric ischemia.

options.label: B
options.text: In patients who are elderly and have substantial comorbidity.

options.label: C
options.text: In patients who are in stable condition and may benefit from transfer to specialized centers.

options.label: D
options.text: In patients who have undergone a cardiac operation in the past 3 weeks

questions.correct_answer: D. In patients who have undergone a cardiac operation in the past 3 weeks
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In patients who have undergone a cardiac operation in the past 3 weeks Because of the risk of aortic rupture, acute ascending aortic dissection is usually considered an absolute indication or emergency surgical repair. However, specific patient groups may benefit from non-operative management or delayed operation. Delayed repair should be considered for patients who (a) present with severe acute stroke or mesenteric ischemia, (b) are elderly and have substantial comorbidity, (c) are in stable condition and may benefit from transfer to specialized centers, or (d) have undergone a cardiac operation in the remote past. Regarding the last group, it is important that the previous operation not be too recent; dissections that occur during the first 3 weeks after cardiac surgery pose a high risk of rupture and tamponade, and such dissections warrant an early operation.

Highyeild:

Acute ascending aortic dissection is a serious condition that requires emergency surgical repair to prevent aortic rupture. However, nonoperative management or delayed operation may be appropriate for certain patient groups. Delayed repair may be considered for patients with severe acute stroke or mesenteric ischemia, elderly patients with substantial comorbidity, stable patients who can benefit from transfer to specialized centers, or patients who have undergone a cardiac operation in the remote past. Dissections that occur within the first three weeks after cardiac surgery pose a high risk of rupture and tamponade and require an early operation.

Extraedge:

The Chest X-ray reveals an enlargement of the superior mediastinum, indicating a possible dissection in the ascending aorta.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of untreated high blood pressure (HBP) had complaints of sudden onset of intense back pain radiating to both arms and shoulders. At admission, the blood pressure (BP) was 210/120 mmHg in both arms, and the pulse was 92 bpm with characteristics of a Corrigan pulse. ECG was normal. Laboratory tests were normal. Chest X-ray showed mild to Moderate mediastinal widening. Transthoracic two-dimensional echocardiography (TTE) showed dilatation of the ascending aorta (51 mm) with an image suggestive of an intimal flapping that was observed in several views suggesting acute Aortic Dissection. What is the immediate step of management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antihypertensive drugs Initial management of all types of aortic dissection includes blood pressure (which is usually high at presentation) control and strict pain management, followed by prompt referral for specialist management. BP should be reduced rapidly In dissection (unlike in other hypertensive emergency conditions).

Highyeild:

Type B (or type III) dissections are initially managed medically with antihypertensive drugs and monitoring on an acute care unit. Intervention is necessary in complicated cases where the pain increases or fails to resolve, or there is evidence of malperfusion.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Percutaneously placed endovascular stents may be used in selective cases, however, is not the immediate 1 st Option: C. Those involving the ascending aorta usually require surgical intervention ( C, and D). Option: D. Delayed repair should be considered for patients who (a) present with severe acute stroke or mesenteric ischemia, (b) are elderly and have substantial comorbidity, (c) are in stable condition and may benefit from transfer to specialized centers, or (d) have undergone a cardiac operation in the remote past.

Extraedge:

Percutaneously placed endovascular stents are the standard intervention of choice for complicated type B dissection. Surgery is only considered in rare cases that are not suitable for stenting.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female was diagnosed with Non-ST-elevated myocardial infarction by electrocardiogram. She had a history of smoking, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hypothyroidism. A coronary angiogram showed critical stenosis of the left anterior descending coronary artery and first obtuse marginal coronary artery. She underwent CABG surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass. Based on the history, which is not considered the risk factor for the development of Ischemic heart disease in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypothyroidism Risk factors for IHD include Advancing age, Male gender, Hyperlipidaemia (D) Diabetes mellitus, Hypertension (B), Smoking (A), Family history of IHD, Obesity, and Reduced physical activity.

Highyeild:

Summary box 59.4 Risk factors for IHD ● Smoking ● Diabetes mellitus ● Advancing age ● Male gender ● Hyperlipidaemia ● Hypertension ● Family history of IHD ● Obesity ● Reduced physical activity IHD presents with principal symptoms of chest pain (angina), breathlessness, fatigue, peripheral edema, palpitations, and syncope. The severity of symptoms and their impact on everyday activities and quality of life are crucial aspects of clinical history. A comprehensive assessment of risk factors should be performed.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Risk factors for IHD include Advancing age, Male gender, Hyperlipidaemia (D) Diabetes mellitus, Hypertension (B) , Smoking (A) , Family history of IHD, Obesity, and Reduced physical activity.

Extraedge:

Clinical examination is vital and should note any signs of myocardial ischemia, such as new murmurs, heart sounds associated with heart failure or stigmata of associated diseases such as diabetes or peripheral vascular disease. The clinical examination may be normal in some cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male had complaints of chest pain, breathlessness, fatigue, swelling, palpitations, and syncope. Which of the following diagnostic tests provides the first indication of ischaemic cardiac disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Resting electrocardiography As a baseline test, a 12-lead resting electrocardiogram (ECG ) often provides the first indication of ischaemic cardiac disease and is essential in the acute clinical setting. A positive test with evidence of ischemia on the ECG (ST depression of ≤ 2 mm ) does not always indicate IHD and a negative test does not always exclude its presence.

Highyeild:

A resting electrocardiogram (ECG) is a baseline test for detecting ischaemic cardiac disease and is essential in acute clinical settings. A 12-lead ECG can provide the first indication of potential heart issues. A normal ECG does not always mean there is no heart disease present, as it may be normal even in the presence of severe multivessel coronary disease.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Exercise tolerance testing (ETT) is a valuable technique for assessing myocardial ischemia, both for diagnostic purposes and as a prognostic tool. Option: C. Echocardiography is valuable for the evaluation of ventricular function and regional wall motion abnormalities, as well as valvular lesions. Option: D. Selective coronary angiography provides the means of accurately diagnosing the presence and extent of CAD and remains the ‘gold standard’ diagnostic technique.

Extraedge:

Previous myocardial infarction (MI) is indicated by Q waves and/or non-specific ST- and T-wave changes on an ECG. Angina can also be detected through ST depression on an ECG.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female had complaints of chest pain, breathlessness, fatigue, sweating, and palpitations. ECG showed ST elevation. Which of the following diagnostic tests is considered a ‘gold standard’ technique for the diagnosis of ischaemic cardiac disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coronary angiography Selective coronary angiography provides the means of accurately diagnosing the presence and extent of CAD and remains the ‘gold standard’ diagnostic technique .

Highyeild:

Coronary angiography is a diagnostic technique used to diagnose coronary artery disease (CAD). The procedure provides high image quality to show the extent, severity, and location of coronary artery stenosis and the quality and size of distal coronary arteries. The procedure can also assess ventricular function and provide information for cardiac surgeons to determine operability, operative risk, and probability of success. "Coronary angiogram, which visualizes the blood flow within the left main coronary artery and its associated branches."

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Echocardiography is not a good modality for ischemia. It is valuable for the evaluation of ventricular function and regional wall motion abnormalities, as well as valvular lesions. Option: B. Computed tomography (CT) (B) allows assessment of coronary disease and provides information about the degree of coronary artery calcification (calcium score)- Agatston score, which is very helpful when stratifying patients to determine which ones will benefit from the more invasive coronary angiography. Option: C. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (C) can be performed to evaluate the ischaemic burden of coronary disease (using pharmacological agents to stress the heart) and to provide details of tissue viability when using gadolinium as a contrast agent.

Extraedge:

Luminal stenosis of coronary arteries and angiographic findings. Minimal Mild Moderate/significant Severe Occluded Angiographic degree of stenosis 0% 20-49% 50-88% >70% reduction Complete occlusion Luminal cross-sectional stenosis 0% 40-60% 75% >>90% 100%

questions.text: A 62-year-old male was admitted electively for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) for ischemic heart disease. Which of the following has the highest patency rate for choosing graft in CABG?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left Internal Mammary Artery (LIMA) The left internal mammary artery (LIMA), or internal thoracic artery, has the highest long-term patency rates of > 98% with improved long-term survival and fewer reoperations.

Highyeild:

LIMA is the preferred conduit for LAD grafting. Evidence suggests a >95% patency rate and lower reoperation rate over 10 years. LIMA avoids late complications of vein graft atherosclerosis. The Operation: Operation starts with harvesting conduits (vein and/or radial artery). The chest is opened via a median sternotomy and LIMA is dissected. The patient is placed on CPB after heparinisation and the heart is arrested. Grafts are anastomosed to coronary arteries distal to the stenoses.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. The use of the radial artery (B) as a second or alternative arterial bypass graft has enjoyed a revival in recent times. Option: C. The long saphenous vein ( C) is the most common vein used as a conduit but shows a limited long-term patency rate (50–60% at 10 years). Option: D. Alternative vein conduits include the short saphenous vein or upper limb veins such as the cephalic vein (D) however, these grafts are associated with poorer long-term patency rates.

Extraedge:

LIMA grafting is particularly effective in patients with diabetes, who tend to have worse outcomes with other methods of coronary revascularization.

questions.text: Coronary angiography showed an occluded right coronary artery, 60% proximal stenosis in the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and 80% stenosis in 1st obtuse marginal (OM1) in a 47-year-old male. His ejection fraction was 50%. A coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) was planned. The surgeon suggested an Allen test. Which arterial graft mandates an Allen test?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radial artery In assessing a patient in whom a radial artery harvest is planned, Allen’s test should be performed to assess the patency and collateral flow of the ulnar artery . Allen’s test is also necessary before cannulating the radial artery or taking ABG from it.

Highyeild:

Allen's test checks the patency and collateral flow of the ulnar artery before radial artery harvesting for arterial grafts. The test involves compressing both radial and ulnar arteries digitally at the wrist while the patient clenches and unclenches their fist, emptying blood from the hand. The ulnar artery compression is then released and the time it takes for the hand to return to its normal color is assessed. If color returns in 5-7 seconds, it confirms patency and collateral flow from the ulnar artery, and it is safe to harvest the radial artery.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A & C. Not related to the Allen test Option: D. Modified Allen’s test is done

questions.text: A 52-year-old male underwent a Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) for ischemic heart disease. What is the most common postoperative complication that can be expected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Poor cardiac output state The myocardial function typically declines in the first few hours following cardiac surgery, presumably in response to an ischemia/ reperfusion-type injury.

Highyeild:

Tachypnea is a common symptom after CABG. Atelectasis and acute respiratory failure can cause tachypnea in CABG patients. Low blood pressure or hypotension is a symptom of acute cardiac failure. In a patient with tachypnea and hypertension after CABG, the most likely cause is acute respiratory failure.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A: Significant bleeding (A) occurs in approximately 2–3% of patients. Option B: Stroke (B) leading to a focal neurological deficit occurs in approximately 2% of patients following CABG. Option C: The most common postoperative arrhythmia is sinus tachycardia closely followed by atrial fibrillation (AF) (D). Bradycardia is seldom seen as a postoperative complication following CABG.

Extraedge:

A myocardial function can decline in the first few hours after cardiac surgery due to ischemia/reperfusion injury. Inotropic agents may be necessary to support heart function and maintain circulation. A persistent low cardiac output state may occur in some patients. Clinical manifestations of low cardiac output include poor peripheral perfusion, low urine output, metabolic acidosis, and low blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of CABG?

options.label: A
options.text: > 50% stenosis of the left main stem (‘critical left main stem disease’)

options.label: B
options.text: > 50% stenosis of the proximal left anterior interventricular artery

options.label: C
options.text: The poor ventricular function associated with multivessel disease

options.label: D
options.text: > 50% stenosis of the right coronary artery

questions.correct_answer: D. > 50% stenosis of the right coronary artery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

> 50% stenosis of the right coronary artery

Highyeild:

Indications for CABG: >50% stenosis of the left main stem (‘critical left main stem disease’) >50% stenosis of the proximal left anterior interventricular artery Three main coronary arteries are diseased (‘triple-vessel disease’) Two-vessel disease including the proximal LAD.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A: Indication for CABG surgery includes > 50% stenosis of the left main stem (A) (‘critical left main stem disease’), Option B: > 50% stenosis of the proximal left anterior interventricular (B) artery, Two or three main coronary arteries diseased (‘ triple-vessel disease ’) and Option C: Poor ventricular function associated with multivessel disease .

questions.text: A 54-year-old male underwent a CABG procedure for his triple vessel coronary artery disease. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, dyslipidemia, and ischemic heart disease. He also had a Family history of IHD. Which of the following risk factor is considered the most common cause for the development of triple vessel coronary artery disease in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dyslipidaemia The underlying pathology is most commonly hyperlipidemia/dyslipidemia leading to the development of atherosclerosis of the coronary arteries in the development of Ischaemic heart disease (IHD). Aggressive LDL control in diabetics has proven to be one of the most effective strategies for reducing IHD.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B & C. also causative factors, but not most important.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man who is a known case of hyperlipidemia, and hypertension, on Coronary angiography showed total occlusion of LAD and D1 (first diagonal artery) arteries with normal right coronary and circumflex arteries. Echocardiography showed an ejection fraction of 50% with no significant valve disease. Which test is considered the ‘Gold standard’ for imaging the anatomy of the heart in IHD?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coronary angiography Coronary angiography is the ‘Gold standard’ for imaging the anatomy of the heart in IHD. Computed tomography (CT) (B) allows the assessment of coronary disease, and the degree of coronary artery calcification. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (D) can be performed to evaluate the ischaemic burden of coronary disease. Nuclear scans are also helpful in identifying ischemic areas of the heart.

Highyeild:

Coronary angiography The gold standard for imaging coronary anatomy Demonstrates extent, severity, and location of stenosis Demonstrates quality and size of the distal arterial tree Aids diagnosis of ischemia Evaluates suitability for surgery Aids in prognostic assessment

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. ECHOCARDIOGRAPHY is useful in the evaluation of ventricular function and regional wall motion abnormalities, as well as valvular lesions. Option: B. Computed tomography (CT) allows the assessment of coronary disease, and the degree of coronary artery calcification. Option: D. CARDIAC MRI helps to evaluate the ischemic burden of coronary disease & provides the details of tissue viability.

Extraedge:

Coronary angiogram showing a tight, critical stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending coronary artery (left); After placement of a bare-metal stent (right). Wellens syndrome

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with on/off chest pains, which increased on exertion, palpitations, difficulty breathing, and excessive sweating. Significant findings in Blood Examination reveals the patient to have Hypercholesterolemia. ECG appears to be within normal limits. The patient is evaluated further under the suspicion of coronary artery disease. Which of the following would be the Gold Standard for its Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coronary Angiography The Patient is being evaluated for CAD. Coronary angiography provides the means of accurately diagnosing the presence and extent of CAD and remains the ‘gold standard’ diagnostic technique.

Highyeild:

Coronary angiography The gold standard for imaging coronary anatomy Demonstrates extent, severity, and location of stenosis Demonstrates quality and size of thedistal arterial tree Aids diagnosis of ischemia Evaluates suitability for surgery Aids in prognostic assessment

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. ECHOCARDIOGRAPHY is useful in the evaluation of ventricular function and regional wall motion abnormalities, as well as valvular lesions. Option: C. CARDIAC MRI helps to evaluate the ischemic burden of coronary disease & provides the details of tissue viability. Option: D. Positron emission tomography (PET) provides information on myocardial perfusion, metabolism, and cell membrane function.

Extraedge:

Coronary angiogram showing a tight, critical stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending coronary artery (left); After placement of a bare-metal stent (right). Wellens syndrome

questions.text: In a patient about to undergo CABG, the following test was performed to assess whether a certain blood vessel can be harvested for the procedure. The vessel is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radial Artery The test is done is called Allen’s test: The patient makes a tight fist while the surgeon compresses both radial and ulnar arteries digitally. The hand is then relaxed and compression of the ulnar artery is released; the speed of returning color to the hand is assessed. If color returns in 5–7 s , patency and collateral flow from the ulnar artery is confirmed. Radial Artery use as a second or alternative arterial bypass graft has enjoyed a revival in recent times. In assessing a patient in whom a radial artery harvest is planned, Allen’s test should be performed to check for adequacy of ulnar collateral flow. COMMON GRAFTS USED IN CABG ARE: Long saphenous vein Short saphenous vein Cephalic vein Internal mammary artery (LEFT-IMA or LIMA Graft) Gastroepiploic artery Inferior epigastric artery

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A. Cephalic Vein harvest does not require any collateral circulation check as Radial Artery Graft does. Option B . The left internal mammary artery (LIMA), or internal thoracic artery, has become the conduit of choice for the LAD. But no use of Allen’s Test. Option D. Basilic Vein harvest, very uncommon, does not require any collateral circulation check like Radial Artery Graft does

questions.text: In a patient with the following CABG the Heart Function was noted to be subpar and ionotropic support was provided. Despite the ionotropic support the patient still has low cardiac output. All of the following interventions can be used in this patient, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardiopulmonary Bypass (CBP) CPB is used during CABG operations. For mechanical support in a recovering heart, the options used are IABP, ECMO, or VAD. If low cardiac output persists despite inotropic support, the heart requires mechanical support while it recovers its function. This includes an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP), ventricular assist device (VAD), & extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). CPB is used in Cardiac Procedures and it has other Alternative uses. But it is not useful in this case scenario.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. IABP is a device that is inserted, either percutaneously or under direct vision, into the common femoral artery. The balloon is triggered by the ECG. It deflates during systole and thereby lowers systemic resistance & inflates during diastole and increases coronary perfusion in addition to augmenting the systemic blood pressure Option: B. VAD is a mechanical circulatory supporting device used to replace the function of a failing heart partially or completely. It can be used for the short or long term. Option: C. ECMO is a circulatory support device that is similar to CPB; however, ECMO can be established using venous access only (called VV-ECMO) or venous and arterial access (VA-ECMO).

questions.text: Identify the procedure being done:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Long saphenous vein harvest The image depicted shows the long Saphenous vein being harvested for use as a graft in a CABG .

Highyeild:

The most preferred graft for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) is the left internal mammary artery (LIMA), followed by the saphenous vein. The saphenous vein is the most commonly used graft for CABG . The reversed saphenous vein is considered the best natural vascular graft. Dacron is considered the best synthetic vascular graft. Dacron is the best vascular graft for suprainguinal bypass, while the saphenous vein is the best for infrainguinal bypass. Dacron is the best vascular graft for the aorta.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The usual site for fasciotomy, which is done to treat compartment syndrome , is the calf. The incision made in fasciotomy is deeper and Option: C. Short saphenous vein is related to the posterior aspect of the leg. Option: D. Endothermal ablation is used for varicose vein disease . A treatment device is used which produces thermal energy that destroys the structure of the vein, resulting in permanent occlusion. It can be laser or RF based.

questions.text: A patient in his late-50s was taken for a CABG procedure, the following steps were observed by the Intern: Patient is Heparinized & Placed on CPB The proximal anastomoses of the graft are completed Grafts are anastomosed to coronary arteries distal to the stenosis Patient is warmed and weaned from CPB Aorta is cross-clamped and the heart arrested Heparin Reversed The correct order of sequence in a CABG procedure:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A>E>C>B>D>F The Steps In CABG Operation are as follows: The operation commences with the harvesting of the conduits, while the chest is opened via a median sternotomy. The patient is typically placed on CPB after heparinization. The heart was arrested with cardioplegia. The grafts are anastomosed to coronary arteries distal to the stenosis The proximal anastomoses of the graft are completed The patient is warmed and weaned from CPB. The heparin is reversed.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Sequence A. Is the correct option with respect to the Steps in CABG Operation. Sequence B. The Proximal anastomoses of the graft are done after the graft is anastomosed to coronary arteries distal to the stenosis. Sequence C. Before the Clamping of the aorta, Heparinization and CPB is established. Sequence D. Before the Clamping of the aorta, Heparinization, and CPB is established.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented to the Emergency with sudden onset pain in his chest, which is radiating to the back. There is a history of uncontrolled Hypertension. A CT scan shows the following abnormality in Thoracic Aorta below Left-Subclavian. What is the initial course of management in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Excision of tear and Graft placement, by Median Sternotomy.

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical repair of Coarctation, by Left thoracotomy.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antihypertensive Medication Rapid reduction of BP is done in dissection, unlike other hypertensive emergency conditions. The symptoms and the CT finding point towards the diagnosis of Aorta Dissection Stanford Type B. Initial management of all types of aortic dissection includes blood pressure control and strict pain management The CT scan findings are that of Stanford Type B Dissection, and at this stage, it is best managed medically with antihypertensive drugs (Beta Blockers).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Stanford Type A is repaired with Excision of tear and Graft placement, by Median Sternotomy, ONLY AFTER initial steps of Blood Pressure and Pain control. Option: B. The use of percutaneously placed endovascular stents is currently the standard Intervention of choice in Complicated Stanford Type B Dissection, showing neurological or other system involvement. Option: D. Definitive treatment of Coarctation of the aorta is Surgical repair by Left thoracotomy. Coarctation Of the aorta is a congenital heart disease, usually diagnosed earlier in life.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man, known as Hypertensive, came into the Emergency Department with complaints of Severe sudden onset chest pain with a tearing intrascapular pain. Inter-Arm Blood Pressure difference is noted. Which of the following is NOT a RISK FACTORS for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Down’s Syndrome The clinical picture of the patient is that of AORTIC DISSECTION.

Highyeild:

The following conditions are a RISK factor for aortic dissection: Age Hypertension Marfan syndrome Pregnancy Connective Tissue Disorders: Ehlers–Danlos Syndrome, Giant cell arteritis, SLE. Coarctation of the aorta Turner or Noonan syndromes Aortic cannulation site (iatrogenic)

Random:

Explanation For All Options:- Option: A. Coarctation of the aorta can lead to AD Option: B. Marfan syndrome can lead to AD Option: C. Ehlers–Danlos Syndrome is a Connective Tissue Disorder that is a risk factor for AD Option: D. DOWN’s Syndrome is not a Risk Factor for Aortic Dissection.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented to the Emergency with Sudden Onset chest Pain radiating to the back, dyspnoea, and palpitations. ECG findings of Myocardial Ischemia are noted. An Urgent CT scan was done, in view of Negative Cardiac Markers. Transient Ischemic Attack Paraplegia Aortic Regurgitation Limb ischemia Which of the following complications can be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, & 4 The case profile and findings are that of an Aortic Dissection Stanford Type A. The Complications of Aortic Dissection are due to the Extension of the tear Proximally OR Distally. The dissection can extend distally down the aorta to involve: The renal arteries (renal pain and renal failure); The mesenteric arteries (abdominal pain and bowel ischemia); The iliac arteries (leg pain, pallor, loss or reduced pulses & limb ischemia). The dissection may track proximally to involve.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option B . The spinal arteries (paraplegia); Option A. The head and neck vessels (symptoms and signs of a stroke or TIA); The coronary vessels (MI); Option C. The aortic root (aortic regurgitation). The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left Hemothorax).

questions.text: The following statement regarding the Treatment Protocol for Aortic Aneurysm are true, EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: 3 can be managed medically if Uncomplicated

options.label: C
options.text: 1, 2, and 3 all require Blood Pressure Control as Initial therapy

options.label: D
options.text: 2 & 3 are treated surgically only if Complicated

questions.correct_answer: D. 2 & 3 are treated surgically only if Complicated
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 & 3 are treated surgically only if Complicated The diagram given is that of AORTIC DISSECTION. Image 1 is Stanford Type A, DeBakey 1 Image 2 is Stanford Type A, DeBakey 2 Image 3 is Stanford Type B, DeBakey 3

Highyeild:

Type A dissections require surgery if involving ascending aorta. The chest opened, CPB commenced, and the aorta cross-clamped Intimal tear excised with ascending aorta if localized Distal anastomosis performed with circulatory arrest Type B dissections are initially managed medically Antihypertensive drugs and monitoring used Intervention indicated in complicated cases Malperfusion symptoms are also an indication for intervention Endovascular stents are currently the standard intervention for complicated type B dissection

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option:A. Stanford Type A (OR TYPE I AND II) DISSECTIONS: Those involving the ascending aorta usually require surgical intervention. If type A dissection is untreated, the mortality rate is 50% within 48 hours and 75% within 1-2 weeks, whereas patients with type B dissections have a better prognosis Option:B. Stanford Type B (OR TYPE III) DISSECTIONS Initially, these are best managed medically with antihypertensive drugs. Intervention is indicated in complicated cases only. Option:C. Initial management of all types of aortic dissection includes a blood pressure control Option:D. Image 2, which is Stanford Type A, has to be treated surgically as it involves Ascending Aorta. Whereas, Image 3, which is Stanford Type B can be managed Medically.

Extraedge:

Untreated type A dissection has high mortality rates (50% within 48 hours, 75% within 1-2 weeks) Type B dissections have a better prognosis Surgical mortality is around 20-25% for proximal aortic dissection

questions.text: A 65-year-old Patient was found to have on-off chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, & palpitations. He underwent a Coronary Angioplasty, which proved the Diagnosis of CAD. The following are the indications for CABG surgery in this patient, Except:

options.label: A
options.text: >50% stenosis of the Left main stem (‘critical left main stem disease’)

options.label: B
options.text: >50% stenosis of the Distal left anterior interventricular artery

options.label: C
options.text: Two or three main coronary arteries are diseased (‘triple-vessel disease’)

options.label: D
options.text: The poor ventricular function associated with multivessel disease

questions.correct_answer: B. >50% stenosis of the Distal left anterior interventricular artery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

>50% stenosis of the Distal left anterior interventricular artery The decision to offer CABG is based on the balance between the expected benefit and the potential risks to the patient. >50% stenosis of the Distal left anterior interventricular artery is NOT an Indication for surgery Indication for surgery: >50% stenosis of the left main stem (‘critical left main stem disease’) >50% stenosis of the PROXIMAL left anterior interventricular artery Two or three main coronary are arteries diseased (‘triple-vessel disease’) The poor ventricular function associated with multivessel disease

Highyeild:

CABG decision depends on benefits versus risks for the patient Two issues need addressing for surgical suitability: revascularization appropriateness and CABG versus PCI Revascularization is justified in patients with persistent symptoms or certain anatomical patterns of disease The current best evidence supports revascularization for symptomatic patients on prognostic grounds

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. >50% stenosis of the Left main stem (‘critical left main stem disease’) is an Indication for surgery Option: C. Two or three main coronary arteries diseased (‘triple-vessel disease’) is an Indication for surgery Option: D. Poor ventricular function associated with the multivessel disease is an Indication for surgery

Extraedge:

EACTS guidelines are helpful for identifying patients with complex coronary anatomy or left main stem disease who could benefit from surgery. These patients can be identified through certain angiographic features.
